title: 103_hr3058
content: The Act titled "Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Convention Act of 1993" represents the United States under the Convention. The Secretary appoints up to three individuals as U.S. Commissioners to the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organization, with at least one from the commercial fishing industry and one from the government. The Secretary appoints U.S. Commissioners to the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organization, with specific qualifications and term limits in place. Alternate Commissioners may be appointed for anticipated absences. The Secretary appoints U.S. Commissioners to the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organization, with specific qualifications and term limits in place. In the absence of a Commissioner, an Alternate Commissioner may be designated to serve at meetings of the General Council or Fisheries Commission. The Secretary appoints up to three individuals as U.S. Representatives on the Scientific Council. The Secretary appoints U.S. Representatives to the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organization Scientific Council, with specific eligibility criteria and term limits in place. Representatives must be knowledgeable about scientific issues and may serve for up to four years, with the possibility of reappointment. Additionally, at least one Representative must be a government official. Alternate Representatives may also be appointed by the Secretary. The Secretary may appoint Alternate Representatives to serve in place of Representatives at Scientific Council meetings. These Alternates have the same powers and duties as the Representatives they replace. Additionally, Commissioners and their Alternates may bring experts and advisers to Organization meetings. Coordination and consultation are key aspects of the functions of Commissioners, Alternate Commissioners, Representatives, and Alternate Representatives under the Convention. Representatives and Alternate Representatives must coordinate with Regional Fishery Management Councils and consult with the committee established under section 9. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to these coordination and consultations. SEC. 3. REQUESTS FOR SCIENTIFIC ADVICE. Requests and specifications must be consulted with Regional Fishery Management Councils and approved by Commissioners before making a request under Article VII(1) or a specification under Article VIII(2) of the Convention for scientific advice on fishery management and conservation in US waters. The Scientific Council considers questions referred to it under the Convention's terms of reference. The Secretary of State has the authority to receive and transmit communications to the Organization, object to proposals of the Fisheries Commission, give notice of intent not to be bound by measures, object to amendments to the convention, and act upon other communications. Interagency cooperation is also emphasized. SEC. 5. INTERAGENCY COOPERATION. The Secretary may arrange cooperation with other US agencies, states, councils, and private entities. Federal agencies can assist the Organization and receive reimbursement. SEC. 6. RULEMAKING. The Secretary will create regulations to implement the Convention and this Act, applicable to all persons and vessels under US jurisdiction. Prohibited acts and penalties are also outlined. It is illegal for any person or vessel under US jurisdiction to violate regulations or measures under the Act or Convention, refuse inspection, obstruct enforcement officers, or resist lawful arrest. Any person who violates regulations under the Act or Convention, refuses inspection, obstructs enforcement officers, or resists lawful arrest may face civil penalties or criminal charges under the Magnuson Act. Any vessel or fish involved in unlawful acts under the Magnuson Act may be subject to seizure and forfeiture. Fish seized can be disposed of by court order or as per regulations. Enforcement is carried out by the Secretary and the Department. The Secretary and the Coast Guard enforce the provisions of the Act, with authority specified in the Magnuson Act. The district courts have exclusive jurisdiction over cases arising under this section and can take various actions in the interests of justice. SEC. 8. UNITED STATES-CANADA FISHERY MANAGEMENT AGREEMENT. The Secretary of State, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, is authorized to negotiate an international fishery agreement with Canada for the conservation of fisheries in the northwest Atlantic Ocean, focusing on groundfish stocks and supporting New England groundfish restoration efforts. The agreement will include exchanges of scientific information on fisheries management. The Secretary of State is authorized to negotiate an international fishery agreement with Canada for the conservation of fisheries in the northwest Atlantic Ocean. The agreement aims to address fisheries stocks of mutual concern, establish routine meetings between officials, identify beneficial conservation measures, and implement agreed-upon measures. The agreement will be subject to existing law and annual updates will be provided to Congress. The Secretary shall provide a letter to Congress detailing activities under this section. SEC. 9. CONSULTATIVE COMMITTEE. Establishment of a consultative committee by the Secretaries of State and Commerce to advise on issues related to the Convention and fishery agreements. Membership includes representatives from various fisheries management organizations and industries, serving two-year terms with eligibility for reappointment. Members may attend meetings related to Northwest Atlantic fisheries organization. The consultative committee advises on agreements related to the Convention and fishery management. Members can attend public meetings of the General Council, Fisheries Commission, and United States Commissioners. The committee is not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. SEC. 10. ADMINISTRATIVE MATTERS. Prohibition on Compensation: Individuals serving in specified roles shall not receive compensation from the Government. Travel and Expenses: The Secretary of State may pay for necessary travel and expenses for certain individuals and experts in accordance with regulations. Status as Federal Employees: Individuals shall not be considered. Status as Federal Employees: Individuals serving in specified roles shall not be considered Federal employees, except for injury compensation and tort claims liability purposes. SEC. 11. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions include terms such as authorized enforcement officer, Commissioner, Convention, Fisheries Commission, and General Council. The General Council, Magnuson Act, Organization, Person, and Representative are defined terms in the Act related to fisheries management. The term "Scientific Council" refers to the Fisheries Scientific Council appointed under the Magnuson Act, while the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Commerce. SEC. 12. Authorization of appropriations for the Act, including $500,000 for each fiscal year 1994-1996.
